post:
How do I drink safely?
Im 16 years old, I was diagnosed with T1D back in June, so about 6 months ago. I have never drank before but I would like to be able to drink with my friends. I understand that drinking can be very dangerous. I have a cgm and a pump and I am using the loop app to manage BG. I read that hard liquor can lower blood sugars, how does that work? Can I get around this by just lowering my basal and not worrying about it? How do I drink safely with T1D?

comments.text:
(Assuming 16 is the legal drinking age in your country)

eat a meal before you start drinking, preferably with a glass of water. 

know what a serving of alcohol is no matter the type of alcohol,

no more than 1 serving of alcohol per hour,

always have a designated driver, I also make sure people know to call 911 if I can't be woken they are not allowed to use my insulin on me.

I drink sugary mixed drinks because I find that drinking lowers my blood sugar enough that my sugary mixed drinks keep me up, but I have to keep something next to the bed, because I usually go low before I wake up the next day. The only way to know how alcohol affects you personally is to keep your CGM close at all times.

When your liver is processing alcohol, it will stop releasing glucose. If you still have basal insulin running at the normal rate, than your blood sugar will drop. There are different strategies for handling this. Lowering your basal rate and/or having a closed loop system do it for you is helpful. Make sure to never drink on an empty stomach. Be mindful that some alcoholic drinks have a lot of sugar and you may not need to bolus as much as you would for a nonalcoholic version of that same drink. Basically, a lot of trial and error. Keep an eye on your blood sugar.  And drink plenty of water. Cheers!

At your age: make sure your parents are OK with it. Seriously. Because if it goes wrong - and at some stage, it will - they need to know what's been going on and not be guessing. Trust me on this. It may have saved my life when I was 17 and stupid.

Have food on board. Don't be alone. Try, if you can, to avoid drinking to excess. Experiment, slowly. I don't mean outrageous mixes, I mean:

* 1 beer on its own, no insulin does: this.
* 1 beer, 1 unit just as I drink it does: this.
* 1 shot, on its own, no insulin, does: this

And so on. It's a little hit or miss. But you'll build your own little library of alcohol affects you. There are generalizations of how alcohol affects T1s. They are generalizations, not universal truths. Hard liquor with no mixers doesn't affect me, nor does white wine. Beer does, and the hoppier/darker it is, the more it does. Insulin required, and no, it doesn't drop me afterwards.

If your parents are cool with it, do the experiment and note taking with them present; that might help them trust you a bit more. If they're not, find your most responsible trustworthy friend and do it with him. Have glucose and insulin nearby and make sure he or she knows the difference.

At some point you're going to fuck up. Practice your apology speech now.

It’s not that dangerous, you have a CGM. People here seem to forget diabetes and drinking has been around a hell of a lot longer than CGMs have. I highly disagree with bringing other people into the fold beyond “hey I’m diabetic, if I ask for sugar bring me sugar” but to each their own. 

Don’t do straight liquor or hunch punch that some dude made for the party. No one that age can pace themselves and it goes off the rails very easily. Beer is awesome. 

Don’t take insulin for any drinks you have. Have low sugar snacks on hand. 

It’s always better to be slightly high than it is to be super low while drinking. Give yourself a buffer. You can always take insulin if you’re running high towards the end of the night. 

You’ll learn how to handle it, folks go way overboard with this, it’s not that complicated. You don’t need insulin for drinks unless you’re smashing a bunch of sugary alcoholic drinks, which, don’t do that. Jack and regular coke? Don’t. Orange juice and vodka? Don’t. Have low supplies and play it safe with a buffer. Easy.
https://www.jdrf.org/t1d-resources/living-with-t1d/food-and-diet/diabetes-and-alcohol/
[deleted]

Please ignore the blanket advice of "your body will do this", "your body will do that". 

There is ZERO guarantee that you will respond in the predictable manner.

For instance, I go high and stay high with alcohol, no matter the type. A shot of straight vodka has the same effect for me as a regular soda. But it lasts longer

The only safer way to drink is start slow, in the safety of your own home, with both high and low supplies and preferably either on your own or with a friend or two.

The more calm and alert you are to your diabetes while drinking, for the first time, the better. 

Finding out how you'll respond at a raging party is not a good idea. 

But, testing the waters on your own can help you during those parties.
Consider adding trusted friends to your CGM follow app, especially for urgent alerts

When I first started drinking (and continuing drinking all night) I used to drink one alcoholic drink, and then a pint of water. I alternated between booze and water until I got older and more experienced with booze.

I would definitely recommend this for anyone, for a number of reasons. 1. You’ll fill up with liquid faster so physically won’t be able to drink as much (good for learning how much alcohol your body can handle, and acclimating your body to alcohol). 2. You’ll be that one annoying prick in the morning who wakes up after a night out with no hangover 😂

I’ve learnt over the years that shots, spirits, liquor, just don’t do my body any favours. This isn’t diabetes related, just me not being able to stomach strong alcohol.

The advice about sticking to beer is good, as it can be gassy, and fills you up quicker, so you physically can’t drink as much alcohol. Same sort of deal as the drinking water in between.

I measured how many milliliters are in my average mouthful. For me 1 gulp is about 50 mL and a sip is about 25 mL. I took different sized mouthfuls of water and spat them into a bowl on my food scale. Did that enough times to find my average. 
When I drink i know how much carbs are per 100mL and the math is pretty simple, just need to keep track of how many sips/gulps u take. I have a scoreboard of how much i drank in my head that i can visualize.

This is also a good hack for if you need to correct a low with a beverage and you dont have any measuring cups‼️

With beer and hard cider i bolus per usual. With hard alcohol i always eat something with it and bolus around 70% of what i usually would(for carbs in food and alcohol combined) For wine i bolus for 25% of the carbs but dont need to eat while drinkinkg (although i usually am lol).

I always eat a handful of nuts and chocolate chips before going to bed after drinking bc its a good fat:carb:protein ratio for me

I was diagnosed at 16, 20 yrs ago. I felt the need to feel *normal* and do normal teen stuff. You can have fun, but please utilize your CGM and don't feed the urge to keep pushing things. I drank in college too, and sometimes I wonder how I didn't die. Drinking too much can spike your sugars like crazy, and then while you're hungover drop like crazy, and when you feeling like dog turds after having a few too many, it's harder to stay on top of actually taking care of yourself, it's not worth it. I wish I could tell my younger self to cool it drinking heavily with peers, having fun and imbibing is not a competition, enjoy your time with friends without thinking you need to drink *all* the drinks. If cannabis is kind to you, it's more fun blazing instead of tying too many on, you won't lose your wits/senses like you will with alcohol. Having fun and exploring is a part of growing up, but please be kind to yourself and please take advantage of the info your CGM provides in this time of discovery. Be safe and trust your common sense!

Assume that you need less insulin when you have been drinking. Especially is you're out dancing, you might not need to correct for highs. 

Don't drink on an empty stomach. 

Always carry glucose tablets and snacks. 

Educate your friends what to do in case you get too low. 

Always eat something (perhaps even without bolusing) before you sleep.

I can only speak for myself but beer is a complete wild card for me. Sometime blood sugar goes up, sometimes it goes down. Every brand and type of beer will be completely different and they don't need to label the nutritional values on the labels (at least here in the UK) 

I tend to drink wine or spirits when going out. They don't have any effect on my blood sugar until i go to sleep when it can drop potentially dangerously low. I lower my basal shot and also make sure i eat before bed. Something fatty like a bag of crisps (potato chips) is perfect for me as they keep slowly releasing carbs for a long time.

Have fun and stay safe. Do not get blackout drunk as that could literally kill you as a diabetic. Don't listen to peer pressure. I still get it sometimes in my 40s and they can fuck right off. I'm not dying for them.

The golden rule is to have a light snack before passing out at the end of the night.

Also just be very cautious about drinking sweet drinks that require injections. Because with the delayed response from the alcohol you can sink very low a few hours after. It's best to keep the drinks low carb so your blood sugars are predictably flat throughout the evening.

Best advice i ever got, was not to eat at least 3 hours before alcohol... 
Yes youll have a stronger effect but...

this way the food  affects on bg wont mix with alcohols affect...

Youll get drunk more easily , so youll drink less for the same buzz...

Wich means less kcal from alcohol...less hangover...
Less spikes in bg...

And also for the first couple of times reduse insulin a bit so u can test how your body reacts...

Ou and yes...choose your poison and stick to it...because different drinks will affect you differently...

Drink with moderation and have some low supplies as well as insulin with you. I would also suggest with each drink to drink a glass of water. Spread out your drinks and watch your readings. Also remember it can continue to affect you hours later so make sure you have so supplies nearby when you go to sleep.

Low % lager and spirits are the best way to drink safely I’ve found. Lager above 5% sends me into the 20’s but 4.5% and below acts like water. Spirits don’t move my levels either way, but you are far more likely to make a bad decision injection or food wise if you’re a bit drunk. 
Good luck geezer.

To be honest, my advice is to leave it alone. But in the real world, most of us will have some drinks eventually. I drank heavily in my 20s, until I got a DWI with a BAC of .0202 so I was over double the legal limit at that time. The whole experience was dangerous - you don't want to go to jail as a T1 - and served as my wake up call.

The important thing is to have some self control. I only go out and drink a couple times a year, I catch a little buzz, and that's it. A few weeks ago I went for dinner and a concert. I had two lite beers (5 carbs each) and two glasses of whiskey (very little to no carbs). This was over the course of about 4 hours. I had a little buzz for a while but I stayed up until about 1am and it wore off. Around 5am I had a mild low in my sleep, down to the low 60s. The CGM didn't wake me for about an hour. It turned out to be not a huge deal, but the combination of sleeping heavy after drinking and low BG can be dangerous. If I had been wasted, it probably would've been a lot worse. Getting really drunk also leads to bad choices, like getting the drunk munchies and eating a bunch of waffles at 2am. That's why I tend to err on the side of caution and drink very moderately...

Alcohol slightly lowers bg and carbs raise bg. Same as always, the trick is to know your carb intake. I drink often and am a relatively healthy T1D.

Most alcoholic drinks are mixed with carbs to make them go down easier. In the case of hard liquor, the mix will determine how to dose insulin (Coke, orange juice, whatever). Diet sodas don't have carbs so I never take insulin when I drink them, same with light beer. (Easiest drinks to drink and not have to think about)

If you drink regular soda or fruit juice to mix or heavy beers or wine, you will want to dose yourself based on how much you're consuming. And after too many drinks it becomes easy to lose track and that's when bg issues will arise. Just remember my first sentence and you will be fine.

Make it simple friend. From an ex drinker and long time t1. Don’t. If you’re friends need you to drink, or if you think you need to drink to have friends, you are going to have a long hard life with t1. Or maybe a short one.

I wouldn’t encourage a 16 year old to drink but if you do. Make sure you have food near you if your sugar drops. Whenever I have work events, my go to beer is Budweiser because it’s low carbs and gives me more respect than a white claw. I’m more of a hard liquor person so I like mixing whiskey with diet soda or vodka with soda water and then putting a mio in there.

i don't drink anymore because of the risks, but if you want to drink, here's how i always used to do it incredibly safely (and by that i mean even tho i've been drunk ive never thrown up from it or gotten blackout drunk):
- #1 advice: have a glucagon kit. learn how to use it and show your friends how to use it. bring an instruction booklet with you where you're drinking. when your liver can't release the emergency sugar you need, the glucagon kit can do it for you. it's like an epi pen for diabetics. 
- my nurses always told me never to bolus for alcohol. if you're eating, bolus for the food, but like has been suggested here already, do lighter boluses. 
- if you have a pump by the time you start drinking, use a temporary lighter basal rate (id suggest -50%). 
- monitor your sugar constantly, every 10 minutes. 
- keep plenty of juice and snacks nearby. 
- in my experience, my sugar goes quite high while drinking/eating - don't correct for it. for me it always plummeted overnight / a few hours later when your body is getting rid of the alcohol. if you're going to sleep, set an alarm for 2 hours and have juice by your bed, or have a friend/family member nearby to check on you overnight. 
- if your sugar is dropping and you feel too drunk to know how to fix it/fix it quickly, don't waste any time: call 911 right away. our bodies as t1ds cannot recover from low blood sugars while drunk. get to a hospital asap because they have glucagon and can help you much faster. 
- pace yourself drinking. you don't have to be wasted to have fun being drunk. this might mean you drink less than others but you can still enjoy it. don't do a ton of shots, go for ciders, or mixed drinks. avoid cocktails with huge alcohol content (like sharing a pitcher of sangria), or wine with high alc. content.
- if you're having a mixed drink, ask for the diet version, so a rum and Diet coke, etc. Mixed drinks with a lot of soda or soda water will be hard to manage because they'll make your sugar go way up then go crashing back down. 
- my last advice is do what makes you comfortable. if drinking feels too scary that's okay. in my experience, when you tell people you don't drink because you're diabetic they're always immediately understanding. 
- if you have a good endocrinologist or diabetes nurse ask them for advice too. like someone mentioned we're not medical experts. however as many of us know, sometimes doctors are stupid about type 1, lol. but hopefully you will have a nurse or endo you really trust one day :) 

hope that helps op. you'll be okay as long ed you're careful!
[deleted]

I find that liquors mixed with a diet or zero sugar mixer hardly affects me. Hard seltzers are amazing too. Like no effect on BG and I have never noticed any kind of after effect with them either. As with anything be responsible and keep an eye on your sugar. But I don’t think alcohol has to be this off limits indulgence that some people make it out to be. Another good idea is to have a close friend or significant other with some basic DM knowledge follow you on the dexcom app so you have a second pair of eyes. Low BG can notoriously resemble someone that is intoxicated. Go out with a fast acting sugar in your pocket for emergencies. But only use it if you can’t get a reg soda first. I once ran into a girl that happened to be T1 with a BG in the 50s and the bars had just closed so we we’re struggling to find a street vendor to get her a reg soda. Don’t let yourself get into this situation. 

I personally recommend Trancend gel packets. I buy them in bulk on Amazon.

Getting used to the feeling of alcohol will be your best help. The first time I drank heavily, I was paranoid that I was low because of how I felt when I was intoxicated. Once I got used to the feeling of alcohol then managing type 1 became easier. Start drinking less and don't get pressured into drinking more than you can handle or want to. Keep yourself safe. Have one of your friends remind you to test. Drink sugar-free if possible.
Don't drink for the first time while out with freinds. Do it at home with your parents present until you learned how  your body handle alchohol and drinks of different sugar and carb levels.
[deleted]

I don't personally drink, but I have been told that if I were to, to have a sober friend who is willing to keep an eye on me for the night, willing and able to wake me up if I were to have a hypo during the night

Can I reserve my pancreas?
My kid is 7 and is T1. I googled for answers to no avail. I am an organ donor, but I wondered if there’s a way to reserve my pancreas for my son to receive when I die? Just curious how I would even go about it.

We are the same blood type, btw.

comments.text: His pancreas still does some jobs. If he were to receive yours, he would trade T1d for immunosuppressants. Most people don’t find that trade off to be worth it. Usually, the people who get pancreas transplants are already getting something else transplanted, like a liver. Since they will require immunosuppressants anyway, the trade off is worth it.

Pancreas transplants are fairly rare, difficult to pull off, and generally only offer a short term benefit.  The immunosuppressants required are probably worse than controlling T1.  If I remember correctly even those with successful transplants have a 50% chance of being back on insulin at five years.  It's a lovely thought to have your kid get your pancreas but it's not really a solution.
The average lifespan of a transplanted pancreas is 10 years. The younger he is when he has a transplant, the more likely he will need more than 1.

Pancreas transplants aren't really a viable method of treating diabetes, and is considered a last resort option. Transplants don't last forever, and some don't even last a year. Even if your son got lucky he'd probably only survive a decade or two after getting a transplant. The half life of pancreas transplants is 11 years, meaning in half of patients who have them the transplant fails before 11 years, and half fail after. As far as I can tell, the record for the longest surviving pancreas transplant is 24 years. 

Type one can be managed for a lifetime, and we're closer and closer to a cure all the time. Your kid has a better chance just living with diabetes and hoping for a cure to be finished than trying to get an unnecessary transplant. I don't want to get your hopes up, but with where we are now it's pretty likely a cure will be possible by the time he is an adult.
Aside from the drawbacks noted by others, you didn't say where you live. It's a bit hard to advise when nobody knows what laws might be applicable in your jurisdiction.

It’s more than just immunosuppressive issues. His pancreas is perfectly fine. T1D isn’t a pancreas issue, it’s and antibody issue. His body is literally attacking the beta cells in the pancreas, causing the pancreas to have issues. He won’t lose the antibodies he has because there was an organ donor. People don’t really do transplants because it’s highly likely the body will eventually attack the new pancreas. There has to be some sort of antibody treatment and immunosuppressive along with the transplant. 

Most the new trials for pancreas treatment are actually trying to find a way to make the antibodies mission of killing the pancreas unsuccessful. When doing so the pancreas should go back to normal and beta cells will work again.

Immunosupressants will be needed. I am not a medical professional but your kid's immune system might think that your pancreas is also a threat so the trade off is not worth it. If they are doing fine without it, then don't let them have the misfortune of a very weak immune system that can cause more issues.

I would strongly advise against pancreatic dontations as a treatment for T1D unless a doctor recommends it for two specific reasons:

Organ transplantation is a serious surgery generally considered a last resort for people with major complications or severely brittle diabetes with complications. This is because receiving an organ through transplanting then requires the receiver to take immunoupressants for life to prevent rejection. This puts them at risk for any number of infections and other medical problems.

Transplantation also does not gaurantee their immune system won't once again attack and destory the islet cells that make insulin. In many cases, a new pancreas only "cures" someone from needing injected insulin for a short period of time.

I woukd recommend talking to your doctor about this option. It's unfortunately not the miracle cure it is sometimes believed to be, absent an emergency situation.

How do I go on a run
I switched to tandem and Dexcom. Gotta be honest not as great as I thought. Anyway I still can’t seem to prevent going low. Any tips in this area would be nice. It doesn’t seem to be as simple as turn on exercise mode and exercise. I wish!

comments.text: Disconnect? Or take the time up front to set up a profile that has much lower basal rates, enact that an hour or two before and then run?

Omg I feel you. No matter what I’ve tried I’ve never been able to run for longer than 20 minutes or so without going low unless I consume a ton of sugar during my runs. Which then makes me feel like crap the rest of the day :( I’d like to know others’ advice on this as well.

I will eat a snack if im below 135/7.5 before a run. You might even notice on some runs the adrenaline will increase your blood sugar. Start small and as you become comfortable, try to increase time / distance etc. It can be done - I have run a marathon & over a dozen half's. Like everything else - it's harder for us than the average person. Good luck!

I’ve never found exercise mode to be useful for cardio because the autoboluses for a rising blood sugar cause me to crash hard. I actually use sleep mode instead when exercising and it’s great because it doesn’t give the autoboluses. Regardless, I also have about 15g of sugar 15 minutes before exercising and another 15g every half hour or so if I’m doing a long run and I’ll stay pretty stable — it’ll be different for everyone but that’s what I’ve found to work for me.

I LOVE my tandem... except when it comes to exercise. If I’m doing intense cardio, I crash really hard really fast. When I first got type one, I would have to be at 250-300 in order to exercise and not crash. My old pump had a setting where you could lower your basal rate by whatever percentage before exercising. That works perfect because I would just take 50% for the hour before. That way I wouldn’t climb too high before or crash during. Because tandem has the control IQ, it automatically corrects me when I’m trying to raise my blood sugar before exercising. It’s super frustrating. I have to turn it off for at least a half hour before exercising. The Exercise Activity setting is useless. I have figured out that breaking my exercise into smaller chunks, like two brisk 30 minute walks a day, is much better- or I will under dose a meal and exercise right after. If I want to do a full hour of cardio, then I usually turn off my pump for 30 minutes before I don’t restart it until 30 to 45 minutes into exercising. I’m not sure which is better- The ups and downs your blood sugar goes through when exercising, or just doing gentle forms of exercise that don’t change your blood sugar but don’t always help with your cardiovascular health.

For me, it really depends on how much insulin on board I have. Running increases seems to at least double my insulin sensitivity. I try to aim for 1 unit or less of IOB before I start. If I am high before, I only take half my normal correction.

Running especially would tank me. What finally worked for me was lowering my basal by 50% about 30 mins before the run and down to 30% before heading out the door. If I had any insulin on board, I would have a light snack (a clementine and some pb for example). I also made sure I had some glucose gels while on my run. 

There was a lot of trial and error and shorter runs to figure this out. Don’t get discouraged! You can do it. 

Also, control iq isn’t for everyone. I also have a dexcom and tslim. While I love them, I do a better job than control iq (it’s not aggressive enough for me).

For me, running in the morning (before breakfast) requires almost no adjustment.  But I can't really do mornings, so in the afternoon, I only run 3 hours after a meal, do a 50 percent basal for 1 hour, and drink a cup of Gatorade right before going out.  For runs over 30 minutes I eat a gu gel at 25 minutes.

running especially would tank me. what finally worked for me was lowering my basal by 50% about 30 mins before the run and down to 30% before heading out the door. if i had any insulin on board, i would have a light snack (a clementine and some pb for example). i also made sure i had some glucose gels while on my run. there was a lot of trial and error and shorter runs to figure this out. don’t get discouraged! you can do it. also, control iq isn’t for everyone. i also have a dexcom and tslim. while i love them, i do a better job than control iq (it’s not aggressive enough for me).

How do I properly take insulin for vegetables and protein?
Hello all, hope everyone's well. UK resident here and I would like to hopefully get some help from friends on this sub.

Recently I've decided I want to start eating healthy, had a bit of a spell of eating so many bags of crisps and choccy bars lol. I have started replacing carb heavy meals (more than 60g carbs) with low carb alternatives so for example for tea today I ate.

- 80g Brussel sprouts
- 80g Carrots
- 80g Broccoli
- 80g cauliflower
- 200g chicken

Now the carbohydrates of this meal added up to around 15g carbs. I also add mint sauce and mix it in for flavour so that is like an extra 5-10g carbs.

So for this meal I take 3 units of Novo-rapid insulin. I have this meal a few times per week however I always notice that my blood sugar levels will rise from around 5.6mmol/L(100.8Mg/dl) to 12(216Mg/dl), about 3 hours later, needing me to take a correction. (Estimation but it always rises a bit)

I've looked at the carb content time and time again and meticiously measured them and they are bang on. I know my insulin sensitivity is ok because when I eat porridge for breakfast my blood sugar goes fine.

So I guess my question is, is there a way to Protein count in diet? Similar to the way we carb count, as I imagine it's the chickens fault? As well as the veg which I think contain protein too.


Thanks all.
Dan

comments.text: Trial and error basically. If 3 units raises it, then try 4.5 or 5.

Hey Dan, fellow UK based T1D here. Are you on a pump? Before I got my pump, my Dr (who works alongside Dr Bernstein and is a massive fan of low carb for t1d) put me on a 'slower acting' insulin just to take for high protein, low carb meals. IIRC it was pig insulin! If I have a lower carb meal now, I take an extended bolus that stops the spike but doesn't cause me to go low.

I had a similar problem to you when i also started low carb (blood sugar rising 3 hours later) and am also currently on novorapid. My workaround at the moment is to give myself some units 1p minutes before i start eating (usually 2 to 4) and then some more units 2 hours later to account for the protein (also usually 2 units, but depends on how much protein i ate.
The Type one diabetes Juicebox podcast has some of the best information on this and so much more! Man, what a difference it has made! Night and day! A 5.5 A1C down from 7.9 that confused the Endo!

Hello! I eat low carb. I bolus for carbs and veggies up front, then I bolus about 2 hours later for the protein. Trial and error, honestly. And different types of protein will raise you differently so it will take practice but generally the protein rise comes 2-3 hours after a meal so you’ll need to plan for it then.
I use regular Insulin and a bit fast acting insulin to cover protein and low-carb meals.
